paragraphs.title: Paragraph 14
paragraphs.text:
%md ## Report Description # #### Datasets Used: core_industry_cube - derived from *'BKDS data'* The Black Knight Home Price Index table provides a comprehensive view of all historical data, geographies, property types, and price tiers. The Home Price Index (HPI) is a statistical model that estimates the median home prices for various geographic areas, such as the national, state, metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), and counties. It also provides data for over 20,000 zip codes. The HPI is calculated on a month-over-month basis, providing a timely estimate of changes in home prices. Overall, the HPI is a valuable tool for analyzing trends in the housing market and for making informed decisions related to buying, selling, or investing in real estate.
#### Description: This notebook contains HPI data. These data set can be subset on bases of User Input 1. Desired Date Range (yyyymm) 2. Geographies(Aggtypename) 3. Property Type( All property Types/Condo/Single Family/) 4. States The data in the HPI (Home Price Index) is sliced by users who apply filters via the included form filters. Power BI can be refreshed to display the respective data fields and charts

msg.data:
Report Description

Datasets Used:

core_industry_cube - derived from 'BKDS data'
The Black Knight Home Price Index table provides a comprehensive view of all historical data, geographies, property types, and price tiers.

The Home Price Index (HPI) is a statistical model that estimates the median home prices for various geographic areas, such as the national, state, metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), and counties. It also provides data for over 20,000 zip codes. The HPI is calculated on a month-over-month basis, providing a timely estimate of changes in home prices.

Overall, the HPI is a valuable tool for analyzing trends in the housing market and for making informed decisions related to buying, selling, or investing in real estate.

Description:

This notebook contains HPI data. These data set can be subset on bases of User Input

  1. Desired Date Range (yyyymm)
  2. Geographies(Aggtypename)
  3. Property Type( All property Types/Condo/Single Family/)
  4. States

The data in the HPI (Home Price Index) is sliced by users who apply filters via the included form filters. Power BI can be refreshed to display the respective data fields and charts

from pyspark.sql.window import Window

#Charting Libraries

df = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM hpi.chpi")
#z.show(df)

# Get row count
rows = df.count()
print(f"DataFrame Rows count : {rows}")
paragraphs.name: Get row count

paragraphs.title: Calculations for columns (REO sales & Short Sales
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark
col_pairs = [("aggregatedhpi", "aggregatedshortsalehpiadjustment"), ("aggregatedhpi", "aggregatedreoadjustment"),("pricetier1sa", "reohpiadjustmenttier1"),("pricetier2sa", "reohpiadjustmenttier2"),("pricetier3sa", "reohpiadjustmenttier3"),("pricetier4sa", "reohpiadjustmenttier4"),("pricetier5sa", "reohpiadjustmenttier5"),("pricetier1sa", "shortsalehpiadjustmenttier1"),("pricetier2sa", "shortsalehpiadjustmenttier2"),("pricetier3sa", "shortsalehpiadjustmenttier3"),("pricetier4sa", "shortsalehpiadjustmenttier4"),("pricetier5sa", "shortsalehpiadjustmenttier5")]
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

def add_multiply_columns(df, col_pairs):
    for pair in col_pairs:
        col_name = pair[0] + "_" + pair[1] + "_P"
        df = df.withColumn(col_name, col(pair[0]) * col(pair[1]))
    return df
df = add_multiply_columns(df, col_pairs)
z.show(df)
paragraphs.name: Calculations for columns (REO sales & Short Sales

paragraphs.title: Lookup table
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# Load data into a DataFrame
#df = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM hpi.chpi")
lookup_table = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM hpi.agg_value_lookup")

# Rename columns in lookup_table by adding '_table2' suffix
lookup_table = lookup_table.select([col(c).alias(c + '_Lookup') for c in lookup_table.columns])
paragraphs.name: Lookup table

paragraphs.title: Merge Lookup and HPI
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import concat

# Assume your DataFrame is named 'df' and you want to concatenate columns 'col1' and 'col2'
df = df.withColumn('lookupcol', concat(df.aggtypename, df.aggvaluecode))


lookup_table = lookup_table.withColumn('lookupcol', concat(lookup_table.aggtypename_Lookup, lookup_table.aggvaluecode_Lookup))

#aggtypecode_table2
# Join the two tables based on the common column 'aggvaluecode'
#result_table = df.join(lookup_table, df.lookupcol == lookup_table.lookupcol_table2, 'left')

df = df.join(lookup_table, ['lookupcol'], 'left')
paragraphs.name: Merge Lookup and HPI

paragraphs.title: Date_Range USER_INPUT
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark
# Set display options
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', 500)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)
pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

# Load data into a DataFrame
#df = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM my_table")

# Define widget inputs
min_date = z.input('Enter Min Date (yyyymm):')
max_date = z.input('Enter Max Date (yyyymm):')


# Filter data based on widget inputs
df_filtered = df.filter((df.dateyyyymm >= min_date) & (df.dateyyyymm <= max_date))

# Display filtered DataFrame

#df_filtered.show()
paragraphs.name: Date_Range USER_INPUT

paragraphs.title: User Input for Geographies and Property Type
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark


import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pandas as pd

# Define widget options
aggtypename_Distinct = [[str(i[0]),str(i[0])] for i in df_filtered.select('aggtypename').distinct().sort('aggtypename').collect()]
propertytypename_Distinct = [[str(i[0]),str(i[0])] for i in df_filtered.select('propertytypename').distinct().sort('propertytypename').collect()]

# Define widget inputs
aggtypename_input = z.checkbox('Select Agg Type Name:', aggtypename_Distinct)
propertytypename_input = z.checkbox('Select Property Type Name:', propertytypename_Distinct)

# Filter data based on widget inputs
df_core = df_filtered.filter(
    (df_filtered.propertytypename.isin(list(propertytypename_input))) &
    (df_filtered.aggtypename.isin(list(aggtypename_input)))
)

# Display filtered DataFrame
#df_core.show()
paragraphs.name: User Input for Geographies and Property Type

paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark
# Get row count
rows = df_core.count()
print(f"DataFrame Rows count : {rows}")

import pyspark.sql.functions as F

# Define widget options

propertytypename_Distinct = [[str(i[0]),str(i[0])] for i in df_core.select('propertystate_Lookup').distinct().sort('propertystate_Lookup').collect()]
#propertystate_Lookup
# Define widget inputs
#aggtypename_input = z.checkbox('Select State Code:', aggtypename_Distinct)
propertytypename_input = z.checkbox('Select Property State Name:', propertytypename_Distinct)

# Filter data based on widget inputs
df_core_State = df_core.filter(
    (df_core.propertystate_Lookup.isin(list(propertytypename_input))) 
)

paragraphs.title: Save the data subset  @ desired location
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.pyspark


# SET THE NAME OF FILE YOU'RE SAVING


file_name = 'df_state_trial.csv'


# DECLARATIONS

import os
user_name = spark.sparkContext.sparkUser()
bucket = os.environ['BUCKET']
path1 = "s3a://"+bucket+'/'+user_name+'/upload/'

URI = sc._gateway.jvm.java.net.URI
Path = sc._gateway.jvm.org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path
path = 's3a://'+bucket+'/'+user_name+'/upload/*'
path2 = 's3a://'+bucket+'/'+user_name+'/upload/'
FileSystem = sc._gateway.jvm.org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem
conf = sc._jsc.hadoopConfiguration()
uri = URI.create(path)
fs = FileSystem.get(uri,conf)
df_core_State.repartition(1).write.csv(path1+file_name, mode="overwrite", header= True)
